title: A Father's Love
body:
“Daddy, my shadow is scaring me.” Choking back tears, my daughter whimpered as she spoke.

Dawn had struggled with phobias from a young age. She’d overcome many of her fears, but new ones always seemed to crop up. I’d try to be encouraging, but truthfully, at times I found my patience waning. Tough love was something I struggled with, and I suspected my actions were enabling Dawn’s behavior — but change is difficult.

“Your shadow? Dawn, a shadow is just your body blocking out light — nothing to be afraid of.” I stroked Dawn’s hair, keeping the tone of my voice calm and soothing.

“When your not around, he tries to get me. He said he wants to take me away!” She sputtered out the words, tears flowing down her cheeks. I wrapped my arms tightly around Dawn, bringing her in close.

“Dawn,” I let out an exasperated sigh, “Remember when you were afraid of the statue at school? What happened then?” I stated matter of factly.

She didn’t immediately respond, taking time to consider her response. Just like her mother, she was stubborn as a mule — one stubborn ass mule. I was sure she’d try and retort how this time was different, just as she did every time.

“You don’t believe me, do you?” Rather than the argument I expected, my daughter sounded defeated.

“Honey, you know you’re my sunshine and moonlight, but this has got to stop — for your own good.”

“Please, let me sleep in your room tonight — please!” The tears started up again, even fiercer than before. Dawn wasn’t listening, this much was clear.

“Alright, alright! You can stay in my room tonight, but the rest of the week you’re sleeping in your own bed — and don’t even think about fighting me on this.” My voice was forceful, hoping to make my point crystal clear.

Before heading upstairs, I warmed a glass of milk for Dawn, something her mother used to do for her. Patting her delicately on the head, I swooped her into my arms and headed for bed.

That night I tossed and turned, unable to sleep. My daughter laid motionless, oblivious to my insomnia — for that I was glad. Laying next to my daughter, my thoughts drifted towards my late wife, painful yet beautiful memories. Three sleeping pills later, I finally drifted into an uncomfortable slumber.

I awoke to Dawn screaming into my ear, as if death himself had come for her.

“Daddy, daddy — he came back!” Her voice was filled with absolute terror.

Half asleep, it took me a moment to register her words. “What in the world are you talking about?” I groggily responded, shielding my eyes from the sunlight streaming through the window. “My shadow, when I woke up he was waiting for me. He told me you were keeping me here and that it was time for me to go — what does that mean?!?!” Her wailing intensified, body seizing with every cry.

The hairs on the back of my neck shot up higher than savannah grass, a cold shiver slowly descending down my spine. That was not the first time I’d heard those words spoken, and I dreaded ever hearing them again.

Right before she passed on, my wife had uttered the same thing to me. Staring at some unseen entity behind me, her ice-cold hands clenching me tightly, she whispered those same exact words — the same fucking thing.

Taking a deep breath to calm myself, I turned towards my daughter — my beautiful daughter. She was my only child, the last thread in this world I had to my wife. The love I felt for her was beyond what I could comprehend, it was a love that stretched beyond the eons, cutting through both life and death. The prospect of losing her, that was a thought I would not even entertain.

“I’m sure it was just a bad dream. I would never let anyone take you away — never ever.”

We spent the rest of the day sitting on the couch watching TV, although Dawn seemed rather disinterested. Physically she was there, but mentally she was not.

“You enjoying the movie buttercup?”

“Yes daddy.” Her response was curt, voice listless.

“Is something wrong sweetheart?” I looked lovingly at my daughter, voice filled with sympathy.

“I don’t think I should be here, Daddy, I need to go — it’s starting to hurt.”

I could see the agony in her eyes, just like her mother before her. It was only a matter of time before the decomposition would begin to set in, no matter how hard I fought to stave it off.

“I’m so sorry, I just — I just can’t let you go.”

I’d already lost her mother, and I had promised myself that I would never let the same thing happen to Dawn. Genes, the silent killer — they never stood a chance in this life, but in the next one I found another way. In death, I had found life.

Dawn’s shadow loomed ominously in the foreground, looking at me with hateful eyes. The natural order had been disturbed, and there was hell to pay for it.
author: SpookBrain
